title: Statistics: Sampling and Inference
description: Explore how to collect and analyze data using random samples to draw conclusions about larger populations. Learn to identify populations and samples, understand why random sampling produces reliable results, compare data sets using measures of center and variability (mean, median, range, MAD), and make informal inferences about two populations based on sample data.
goals: Distinguish between a population and a sample and explain why sampling is necessary
Understand that a random sample is likely to be representative and support valid inferences about a population
Compare two data sets by computing and interpreting mean, median, range, and mean absolute deviation (MAD)
Draw informal inferences about two populations based on measures of center and variability from random samples
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release: concept-intro -> I Do -> We Do -> You Do
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank
Real-world contexts (sports scores, school data, surveys) keep problems relatable for 12-13 year olds
Emphasis on computing and interpreting mean, median, range, and MAD — not just calculating but explaining what the numbers mean
Inference questions require written justification comparing the difference in means to the variability within groups

scaffold.title: Populations and Samples
scaffold.content: When we want to learn something about a large group, it is often impossible or impractical to collect data from every single member. Instead, we collect data from a smaller part of the group and use it to draw conclusions about the whole group.
keyPoints: A population is the entire group you want to learn about (e.g., all 7th graders in a school district).
A sample is a smaller subset of the population that you actually collect data from (e.g., 50 randomly selected 7th graders).
We use samples because studying an entire population is often too expensive, too time-consuming, or physically impossible.
The goal of sampling is to learn about the population without having to measure every single member.
A good sample should be representative — it should reflect the characteristics of the whole population as closely as possible.
Example: A farmer with 2,000 apple trees inspects 75 trees to check for disease. The population is all 2,000 trees; the sample is the 75 inspected.

scaffold.title: Random Sampling and Why It Matters
scaffold.content: Not all samples are equally useful. The way you choose your sample has a big impact on whether your conclusions about the population will be accurate. Random sampling is the gold standard because it helps avoid bias.
keyPoints: A random sample is one where every member of the population has an equal chance of being selected.
Random sampling helps produce a representative sample — one that looks like a mini version of the population.
A biased sample systematically favors certain members over others, leading to conclusions that do not reflect the true population.
Example of bias: Surveying only students in the cafeteria about lunch preferences misses students who bring lunch from home.
Common random sampling methods: assign each member a number and use a random number generator, or draw names from a hat.
Larger random samples generally give more reliable results than smaller ones, but even a small random sample is better than a large biased one.
A single random sample may not perfectly match the population — this natural variation is expected and is called sampling variability.

scaffold.title: Comparing Data Sets with Measures of Center and Variability
scaffold.content: To compare two groups, we use numbers that summarize the data. Measures of center tell us what is typical, and measures of variability tell us how spread out the data is. Using both together gives a complete picture.
keyPoints: Mean (average) = sum of all values divided by the number of values.
Median = the middle value when data is arranged from least to greatest. If there is an even number of values, average the two middle values.
Range = maximum value minus minimum value. It measures the total spread.
Mean Absolute Deviation (MAD) = the average distance each data point is from the mean. A smaller MAD means data is clustered closer to the mean.
To compute MAD: (1) find the mean, (2) find the absolute value of each data point minus the mean, (3) average those absolute values.
When comparing two groups, look at BOTH center and variability — two groups can have the same mean but very different spreads.
A group with a smaller MAD and range is more consistent; a group with a larger MAD and range has more variation.

scaffold.title: Drawing Informal Inferences from Data
scaffold.content: An inference is a conclusion you draw about a population based on sample data. In 7th grade, we make informal inferences — using what we know about center and variability to decide whether two populations are meaningfully different.
keyPoints: An informal inference uses sample data to make a reasonable conclusion about a larger population.
To compare two populations, take a random sample from each and compare their measures of center and variability.
If the difference between the two sample means is large compared to the variability (MAD) within each group, the populations are likely different.
If the difference between the means is small compared to the MAD, the difference might just be due to sampling variability — you cannot confidently say the populations differ.
Always reference specific numbers when stating an inference: mention the means, the difference, and the MADs.
Example: If School A's sample mean is 78 (MAD 5) and School B's is 85 (MAD 4), the 7-point gap is larger than either MAD, so School B likely scores higher overall.

examples.problem: A city has 50,000 households. A research company surveys 500 randomly selected households about their internet usage. Identify the population and the sample, and explain why the researchers used a sample.
examples.solution:
Population: all 50,000 households in the city.
Sample: the 500 households that were surveyed.
Why sample? Contacting and surveying all 50,000 households would be extremely expensive and time-consuming. A sample of 500 gives the researchers a manageable amount of data that can still represent the whole city.

examples.problem: A student wants to know the average number of pages in books at the school library. The library has 8,000 books. He walks to the nearest shelf and picks 20 books. Identify the population and the sample.
examples.solution:
Population: all 8,000 books in the school library.
Sample: the 20 books the student picked from the nearest shelf.
Note: This sample may not be representative because the nearest shelf likely contains books from the same section (e.g., all fiction or all science). Books in different sections may have very different page counts.

examples.problem: A veterinarian wants to estimate the average weight of golden retrievers in the United States. She records the weights of 120 golden retrievers that visit her clinic over a year. What is the population? What is the sample?
examples.solution:
Population: all golden retrievers in the United States.
Sample: the 120 golden retrievers that visited her clinic.
Note: This sample could be biased because dogs that visit the vet may be sick (and possibly underweight) or may come from one geographic area. A truly representative sample would need dogs from many different locations and backgrounds.

examples.problem:
A teacher wants to know how 7th graders at her school feel about the lunch menu. She considers two methods.

Method A: Ask students she sees in the cafeteria during lunch.
Method B: Assign each 7th grader a number and use a random number generator to select 40 students.

Which method produces a random sample? Explain why the other method could be biased.
examples.solution:
Method B produces a random sample because every 7th grader has an equal chance of being selected by the random number generator.

Method A is NOT random and could be biased. Students in the cafeteria are those who buy school lunch, so they may have different opinions about the menu than students who bring lunch from home. The sample would over-represent lunch buyers and under-represent lunch bringers.

examples.problem:
A sports reporter wants to estimate the average height of players in a basketball league with 400 players. She considers two approaches.

Method A: Measure the 30 tallest players.
Method B: Put all 400 names in a hat and draw 30 names.

Which method will give a more accurate estimate? Explain.
examples.solution:
Method B will give a more accurate estimate. Drawing names from a hat is random — every player has an equal chance of being selected.

Method A deliberately selects the tallest players, which guarantees the sample average will be much higher than the true population average. This is a biased sample because it systematically excludes shorter players.

Using Method B, the sample will likely include tall, average, and shorter players, giving a much more realistic estimate of the league's true average height.

examples.problem: A principal wants to survey 60 students from a school of 600 about whether they want a longer recess. She prints out an alphabetical list of all 600 students and selects every 10th name on the list. Is this a valid random sampling method? Why or why not?
examples.solution:
Yes, this is a valid random sampling method called systematic sampling. As long as the alphabetical list has no hidden pattern related to recess preferences (and it wouldn't — last names are unrelated to opinions about recess), every student has an equal chance of being selected.

The method produces 600 / 10 = 60 students, which is the desired sample size. This is a practical alternative to drawing names from a hat when the population list is long.

examples.problem:
Two basketball teams recorded their points scored in their last 5 games.

Team A: 68, 72, 75, 70, 80
Team B: 60, 85, 65, 90, 70

Compute the mean, median, range, and MAD for each team. Then compare the two teams.
examples.solution:
Team A:
  Mean = (68 + 72 + 75 + 70 + 80) / 5 = 365 / 5 = 73
  Sorted: 68, 70, 72, 75, 80 -> Median = 72
  Range = 80 - 68 = 12
  MAD: |68-73| + |72-73| + |75-73| + |70-73| + |80-73| = 5 + 1 + 2 + 3 + 7 = 18
  MAD = 18 / 5 = 3.6

Team B:
  Mean = (60 + 85 + 65 + 90 + 70) / 5 = 370 / 5 = 74
  Sorted: 60, 65, 70, 85, 90 -> Median = 70
  Range = 90 - 60 = 30
  MAD: |60-74| + |85-74| + |65-74| + |90-74| + |70-74| = 14 + 11 + 9 + 16 + 4 = 54
  MAD = 54 / 5 = 10.8

Comparison: The two teams have similar means (73 vs 74), so their typical performance is about the same. However, Team B is far more inconsistent — their range (30 vs 12) and MAD (10.8 vs 3.6) are much larger. Team A scores within a narrow band, while Team B swings between very low and very high games.

examples.problem:
Two study groups took a practice quiz (scored out of 100).

Group X: 70, 75, 80, 85, 90
Group Y: 76, 78, 80, 82, 84

Compute the mean, median, range, and MAD for each group. Which group was more consistent?
examples.solution:
Group X:
  Mean = (70 + 75 + 80 + 85 + 90) / 5 = 400 / 5 = 80
  Sorted: 70, 75, 80, 85, 90 -> Median = 80
  Range = 90 - 70 = 20
  MAD: |70-80| + |75-80| + |80-80| + |85-80| + |90-80| = 10 + 5 + 0 + 5 + 10 = 30
  MAD = 30 / 5 = 6

Group Y:
  Mean = (76 + 78 + 80 + 82 + 84) / 5 = 400 / 5 = 80
  Sorted: 76, 78, 80, 82, 84 -> Median = 80
  Range = 84 - 76 = 8
  MAD: |76-80| + |78-80| + |80-80| + |82-80| + |84-80| = 4 + 2 + 0 + 2 + 4 = 12
  MAD = 12 / 5 = 2.4

Comparison: Both groups have the same mean (80) and median (80), so their typical scores are identical. However, Group Y is much more consistent — their range (8 vs 20) and MAD (2.4 vs 6) are both smaller. Group X had a wider spread of scores from 70 to 90, while Group Y's scores were tightly clustered between 76 and 84.

examples.problem: A random sample of 20 students from School A had a mean math test score of 78 with a MAD of 5. A random sample of 20 students from School B had a mean of 85 with a MAD of 4. Can you conclude that School B students generally score higher in math?
examples.solution:
Difference in means: 85 - 78 = 7 points.
The MADs are 5 and 4, so the typical variation within each school is about 4 to 5 points.

The 7-point difference between the schools is larger than the variability within either school. This means the gap is unlikely to be caused by random chance alone.

Inference: Yes, it is reasonable to conclude that students at School B generally score higher in math than students at School A. The difference in sample means (7 points) is meaningfully larger than the typical spread within each group.

examples.problem: A gardener tested two fertilizers. A random sample of 15 plants given Fertilizer X grew a mean of 12 cm with a MAD of 3 cm. A random sample of 15 plants given Fertilizer Y grew a mean of 13 cm with a MAD of 4 cm. Is there evidence that one fertilizer works better?
examples.solution:
Difference in means: 13 - 12 = 1 cm.
The MADs are 3 cm and 4 cm, so the typical variation within each group is 3 to 4 cm.

The 1 cm difference between the groups is much smaller than the variability within each group. This means the difference could easily be due to natural variation in plant growth rather than a real difference between the fertilizers.

Inference: There is not enough evidence to conclude that one fertilizer works better than the other. The difference in means (1 cm) is small compared to the MADs (3-4 cm), so it could just be sampling variability.

examples.problem: A random sample of 25 runners from the track team had a mean mile time of 7.2 minutes with a MAD of 0.6 minutes. A random sample of 25 runners from the soccer team had a mean mile time of 8.0 minutes with a MAD of 0.8 minutes. What can you infer?
examples.solution:
Difference in means: 8.0 - 7.2 = 0.8 minutes.
The MADs are 0.6 and 0.8 minutes.

The 0.8-minute difference is comparable to the MADs. It is right at the boundary — the difference is about the same size as the variability within each group.

Inference: There is some evidence that track team runners tend to have faster mile times than soccer team runners, but the evidence is not overwhelming. The difference (0.8 min) is close to the typical variation within each team (0.6 to 0.8 min), so additional data would help strengthen this conclusion.

scaffold.title: Populations, Samples, and Random Sampling Practice

problems.problem: A school has 800 students. The principal wants to know how many hours per week students spend on homework. She randomly selects 50 students from the school roster and surveys them. Identify the population and the sample. Then explain why using a sample makes sense here.
hints: The population is the entire group the principal wants to learn about.
The sample is the smaller group she actually collects data from.
Think about what would happen if she tried to survey all 800 students.
problems.answer: Population: all 800 students at the school. Sample: the 50 students who were surveyed. Using a sample makes sense because surveying all 800 students would take a very long time and be difficult to organize. A random sample of 50 can give a good estimate of the homework habits of the entire school.

problems.problem: A town has 5,000 residents. A researcher wants to know if residents support building a new park. She stands outside a grocery store on a Tuesday morning and asks 100 people who walk by. Is this a random sample? Explain why or why not, and describe how the sampling method could affect the results.
hints: For a sample to be random, every member of the population must have an equal chance of being selected.
Think about who is likely to be at a grocery store on a Tuesday morning. Who would be missing?
Consider how a different sampling method could better represent the whole town.
problems.answer: This is NOT a random sample. People at a grocery store on a Tuesday morning do not represent all 5,000 residents. People who work during the day, students in school, and residents who shop at other stores or on other days are excluded. The results could be biased — for example, retirees and stay-at-home parents might be over-represented, and their opinions about a park could differ from the broader population. A better method would be to randomly select 100 addresses from the town directory and mail or deliver surveys to those households.

scaffold.title: Comparing Data Sets and Drawing Inferences

problems.problem:
Two soccer teams recorded the number of goals they scored in each of their last 5 games.

Team A: 2, 3, 1, 4, 5
Team B: 3, 3, 2, 4, 3

Compute the mean, median, range, and MAD for each team. Which team is more consistent? Explain using the data.
hints: Start by finding the mean of each team: add all goals and divide by 5.
Sort each data set to find the median (middle value).
For MAD: find the distance of each value from the mean, then average those distances.
Team A mean = 15/5 = 3. Team B mean = 15/5 = 3. Now compare their variability.
problems.answer:
Team A: Mean = (2+3+1+4+5)/5 = 15/5 = 3. Sorted: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. Median = 3. Range = 5-1 = 4. MAD: (|2-3|+|3-3|+|1-3|+|4-3|+|5-3|)/5 = (1+0+2+1+2)/5 = 6/5 = 1.2.

Team B: Mean = (3+3+2+4+3)/5 = 15/5 = 3. Sorted: 2, 3, 3, 3, 4. Median = 3. Range = 4-2 = 2. MAD: (|3-3|+|3-3|+|2-3|+|4-3|+|3-3|)/5 = (0+0+1+1+0)/5 = 2/5 = 0.4.

Both teams have the same mean (3) and median (3), but Team B is more consistent. Team B has a smaller range (2 vs 4) and a much smaller MAD (0.4 vs 1.2), meaning their scores are clustered closer to the average. Team A's scoring varies more widely from game to game.

problems.problem: A random sample of 30 seventh graders from Lincoln Middle School had a mean height of 62 inches with a MAD of 2.5 inches. A random sample of 30 seventh graders from Washington Middle School had a mean height of 59 inches with a MAD of 2 inches. What informal inference can you draw about the heights of seventh graders at these two schools? Use the data to justify your answer.
hints: Find the difference between the two sample means.
Compare that difference to the MADs. Is the gap between schools large or small relative to the spread within each school?
The difference in means is 62 - 59 = 3 inches. Both MADs are around 2 to 2.5 inches.
problems.answer: The difference in means is 62 - 59 = 3 inches. Both MADs are relatively small (2.5 and 2 inches), meaning students within each school have heights that are fairly close to their school's average. The 3-inch difference between the schools is larger than either MAD, which suggests the difference is meaningful and not just due to random chance. Inference: Seventh graders at Lincoln Middle School are likely taller on average than seventh graders at Washington Middle School.

scaffold.title: Statistics: Sampling and Inference — Practice Set

problems.problem: A factory produces 10,000 light bulbs every day. A quality inspector randomly selects 200 bulbs from the production line and tests whether they work. Identify the population and the sample. Why is it impractical to test every bulb?
problems.answer: Population: all 10,000 light bulbs produced that day. Sample: the 200 bulbs selected and tested. Testing every bulb is impractical because it would be extremely time-consuming and costly. Some quality tests may also damage or destroy the bulbs, so testing all of them would leave none to sell.

problems.problem: The student council wants to find out what theme 7th graders prefer for the school dance. They survey all 40 members of the drama club. Is this a representative sample of all 7th graders? Explain why or why not, and suggest a better method.
problems.answer: No, this is not a representative sample. Drama club members are a specific group that may have different interests and preferences compared to the general 7th grade population — for example, they might prefer creative or theatrical themes. A better method would be to get a list of all 7th graders and randomly select students from that list, such as using a random number generator to pick 40 students from the full roster. This way every 7th grader has an equal chance of being chosen.

problems.problem:
Two classes took the same science test. Here are 5 randomly selected scores from each class.

Ms. Rivera's class: 70, 75, 80, 85, 90
Mr. Chen's class: 76, 78, 80, 82, 84

Compute the mean, median, range, and MAD for each class. Then write 2-3 sentences comparing the two classes.
problems.answer:
Ms. Rivera's class: Mean = (70+75+80+85+90)/5 = 400/5 = 80. Median = 80. Range = 90-70 = 20. MAD = (|70-80|+|75-80|+|80-80|+|85-80|+|90-80|)/5 = (10+5+0+5+10)/5 = 30/5 = 6.

Mr. Chen's class: Mean = (76+78+80+82+84)/5 = 400/5 = 80. Median = 80. Range = 84-76 = 8. MAD = (|76-80|+|78-80|+|80-80|+|82-80|+|84-80|)/5 = (4+2+0+2+4)/5 = 12/5 = 2.4.

Both classes have the same mean and median of 80, so the typical performance is identical. However, Mr. Chen's class is much more consistent — the range (8 vs 20) and MAD (2.4 vs 6) are both smaller. Ms. Rivera's class has a wider spread of scores, with some students scoring much higher and some much lower than the average.

problems.problem:
Two basketball players each attempted 10 free throws in 5 separate practice sessions. Here is the number of free throws made per session.

Player A: 6, 7, 8, 7, 7
Player B: 4, 9, 5, 10, 7

Compute the mean, median, range, and MAD for each player. Who is the more reliable free-throw shooter? Explain.
problems.answer:
Player A: Mean = (6+7+8+7+7)/5 = 35/5 = 7. Sorted: 6, 7, 7, 7, 8. Median = 7. Range = 8-6 = 2. MAD = (|6-7|+|7-7|+|8-7|+|7-7|+|7-7|)/5 = (1+0+1+0+0)/5 = 2/5 = 0.4.

Player B: Mean = (4+9+5+10+7)/5 = 35/5 = 7. Sorted: 4, 5, 7, 9, 10. Median = 7. Range = 10-4 = 6. MAD = (|4-7|+|9-7|+|5-7|+|10-7|+|7-7|)/5 = (3+2+2+3+0)/5 = 10/5 = 2.

Both players have the same mean (7) and median (7), but Player A is the more reliable shooter. Player A's range is only 2 (compared to 6) and MAD is only 0.4 (compared to 2), meaning Player A makes very close to 7 free throws every session. Player B is unpredictable — sometimes making as few as 4 and as many as 10.

problems.problem: A random sample of 25 students from Riverside Middle School spent a mean of 45 minutes per night on homework with a MAD of 10 minutes. A random sample of 25 students from Hilltop Middle School spent a mean of 60 minutes per night with a MAD of 8 minutes. Draw an informal inference comparing the homework habits of students at these two schools. Justify your answer using the data.
problems.answer: The difference in means is 60 - 45 = 15 minutes. The MADs are 10 minutes (Riverside) and 8 minutes (Hilltop), so the typical variation within each school is about 8 to 10 minutes. The 15-minute difference between the schools is larger than the variation within either school, which suggests the difference is real and not just due to sampling variability. Inference: Students at Hilltop Middle School likely spend more time on homework per night than students at Riverside Middle School.

answerKeys.gp1-pop-sample: Population: all 800 students. Sample: the 50 students surveyed.
answerKeys.gp1-random-sampling: Not a random sample. People at a grocery store on a Tuesday morning are not representative of all 5,000 residents.
answerKeys.gp2-compare-teams: Both teams: mean 3, median 3. Team B is more consistent (MAD 0.4 vs 1.2, range 2 vs 4).
answerKeys.gp2-inference-heights: Lincoln students are likely taller on average (62 vs 59 inches). The 3-inch gap exceeds both MADs (2-2.5 inches).
answerKeys.ip-pop-sample: Population: all 10,000 light bulbs. Sample: the 200 tested. Testing all is impractical due to cost and time.
answerKeys.ip-random-sampling: Not representative. Drama club has unique preferences. Better: randomly select from full 7th grade roster.
answerKeys.ip-compare-classes: Both classes: mean 80, median 80. Mr. Chen's class more consistent (MAD 2.4 vs 6, range 8 vs 20).
answerKeys.ip-compare-freethrows: Both players: mean 7, median 7. Player A more reliable (MAD 0.4 vs 2, range 2 vs 6).
answerKeys.ip-inference-homework: Hilltop students likely spend more time on homework. 15-minute difference exceeds both MADs (8-10 min).
